prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: band6 obs
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: band 6 setup for continuum, CO/13CO/C18O 2-1 at 0.1 km/s resolution

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The proposed correlator setup is close to the standard Band 6b setup. We will simultaneously cover 12CO 2-1 in baseband 1, and 13CO/C18O 2-1 in baseband 3. In addition, baseband 3 will also cover a proposed shock tracer for the protoplanetary disk, the SO 6(5)-5(4) line (Sakai et al. 2013).
The ~0.167 km/s velocity resolution of baseband 3 is typical to the 13CO/C18O observations of protoplanetary disks. The 12CO 2-1 line in the baseband 1 is covered with a high velocity resolution (0.079 km/s) setup as a result of the Local Oscillator limitation.
The baseband 2 and 4 will cover the continuum emission with a broader bandwidth. In addition, baseband 2 will cover the deuterated species N2D+ 3-2. Baseband 4 will cover the shock tracer SiO 5-4, and the deuterated species DCO+ 3-2 and DCN 3-2. To allow the better detections of these lines and allow the better continuum baseline fitting, we will use the 1.3 km/s velocity for these two basebands. We may detect more lines. Given that the chemistry in these disks is potentially interesting to the community, we will not perform online spectral averaging, to preserve the treasurable information.

Our targets are protoplanetary disks with radii ranging from a few tens to, at most, a few hundred AU. The proposed Band 6 observations at ~0".24 resolution is optimized between the demand in resolving power, and the brightness sensitivity to image the outer regions of the disk. The maximum recoverable angular size is 3".5, which corresponds to a disk radius of 460 AU. Dust emission is usually concentrated to the smaller scales. The 13CO/C18O 2-1 emission are localized to smaller scale in individual velocity channels. Based on our SMA survey on Taurus sources (Figure 2), we think for our major purposes of observing dust emission, 13CO, and C18O, a single pointing with the 12m-array is sufficient to image each disk and recover all the flux; the ACA is not necessary.
The much larger scale and lower surface brightness line and continuum emission from the molecular cloud will be resolved out (as we have found in our Taurus SMA observations - see Figure 2). The ALMA cycle-3 snapshot uv-coverage is denser than hour long integrations with 8-element SMA and therefore clearly sufficient for our purpose. High velocity molecular jet knots may be observed well with the proposed 12CO 2-1 line. The extended molecular outflow may be subject to missing flux, however, is beyond our major science purposes.

The proposed observations can detect 0.1 Jupiter mass (M_J) of dust in each synthesized beam. This dust mass sensitivity is estimated based on the standard optically thin formula introduced in Hildebrand (1983) and Lis et al. (1998), assuming dust opacity spectral index ~1, and dust temperature ~25 K.
The proposed 13CO/C18O 2-1 observations (assuming a typical linewidth of 3 km/s) will achieve an rms noise level of ~13 mJy/beam km/s in each 0".2 beam for the integrated line intensity. According to our developed method for analyzing the line ratios (see Science Justifications), the 13CO/C18O observations together will be sensitive to gas mass of ~0.3 M_J. The observations of 13CO and 12CO alone will be a lot more sensitive to gas, although their correlation with gas mass have larger dispersions. The proposed sensitivity therefore is directly relevant to the planet formation, and can be achieved with the modest observing time request.
To preserve potentially useful information in gas kinematics and astrochemistry, we do not want to use spectral averaging.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The well clustered young stellar objects (YSOs) concentrated to the nearby (130 pc) molecular hub-filament system, Corona Australis (CrA), are by far the least explored by millimeter interferometry owing to the -37 deg Decl. Their wide ranges in disk initial conditions, ambient environments, and evolutionary pathways are ultimately linked to a diversity of planetary systems. The proximity of CrA now permits taking full advantage of ALMA's imaging capability to survey a large number of YSOs with good sensitivity and spatial resolution. We propose to resolve the gas and dust content of all 43 known protoplanetary (Class II) disks in this region with a ~0".24 (30 AU) beam. We will make impact to the community by revealing fundamental disk properties including the dust/gas density profile, morphology (cavity, azimuthal asymmetry, and multiplicity), and gas motions including rotation, radial flows, and jet/outflow, in great details. These statistically significant, unbiased and homogeneous disk samples will achieve a mass sensitivity to 0.1 Jupiter massse in dust, and ~<0.3 Jupiter masses in 13CO/C18O line ratio, which will define a realistic parameter space for planet formation models.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
